headline.main: A.I.G. Repays N.Y. Fed and Looks to Big Stock Sale

docs.abstract: A.I.G. paid off its obligations to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, paving the way for the insurer and the Treasury Department to plan for a huge sale of stock this spring.
docs.snippet: A.I.G. paid off its obligations to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, paving the way for the insurer and the Treasury Department to plan for a huge sale of stock this spring.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here is some reader response via e-mail to my most recent column from last Sunday, Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift.

headline.main: Letters: Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift

docs.abstract: Readers weigh in with their thoughts to the Public Editor's most recent column, Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift.
docs.snippet: Readers weigh in with their thoughts to the Public Editor's most recent column, Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift.

docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of the health law sometimes like to suggest that cutting health costs would be easy, if only we'd be willing to try common-sense ideas. But that's wishful thinking. The law does include most of the common-sense ideas supported by health economists ranging from Mark McClellan (the former Bush administration official) to David Cutler (a former Clinton and Obama adviser). There's just no getting around the fact that reducing the growth rate of health costs will be difficult.
docs.abstract: Opponents of the health law sometimes suggest that cutting costs would be easy, with common-sense ideas. Several writers -- David Wessel, most recently -- have recently explained why that's not so.
docs.snippet: Opponents of the health law sometimes suggest that cutting costs would be easy, with common-sense ideas. Several writers -- David Wessel, most recently -- have recently explained why that's not so.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Palestinian girl paralyzed in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza will be allowed to remain in Israel for medical care, according to a government document released Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The good news about the shingles vaccine, recommended for all adults age 60 or older with normal immune systems, is that it works even better than scientists first thought.

headline.main: Few Takers for the Shingles Vaccine

docs.abstract: The shingles vaccine may be even more effective than first thought, scientists said on Tuesday. So why aren't more of the elderly getting it?
docs.snippet: The shingles vaccine may be even more effective than first thought, scientists said on Tuesday. So why aren't more of the elderly getting it?

docs.lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. doesn’t have enough data to judge whether lap bands can help not-so-obese people safely lose weight and keep it off.
